In this world, the steam engine never roared to life, and the iron giants of progress never clanked across the countryside. Instead, the air hums with the quiet song of wind chimes and the rustle of paper sails on riverboats powered by the breath of the earth itself. The cities rise not from coal and steel, but from living wood, woven like tapestries of roots and vines, their spires shaped by the hands of tree-sculptors who speak to the forest in ancient tongues. The streets are paved not with asphalt, but with polished river stones, each one a memory of the water’s journey. The world breathes slowly, deeply, and the people move with the rhythm of the seasons, not the clock.

In this world, the factories never loomed, and the smoke never choked the sky. Instead, the workshops are nestled in the hollows of ancient trees, where artisans craft tools from bone, stone, and the polished shells of sea creatures. The looms are not driven by steam, but by the gentle pull of handwoven threads, each pattern a story passed down through generations. The air is thick with the scent of beeswax, wild herbs, and the earth after rain. The people do not rush. They wait. They listen. They dream. The world is not faster, but deeper.

In this world, the railroads never cut through the land like scars, and the trains never screamed across the plains. Instead, the roads are paths of moss and stone, winding through meadows and forests, where travelers ride on the backs of great, gentle beasts—lions with kind eyes, deer with silver antlers, and birds whose wings carry them like clouds. The journey is not measured in miles, but in moments: the time it takes to watch a fox cross the path, the moment a star appears in the twilight. The world is not conquered. It is *walked*.

In this world, the machines never took over, and the hands of the people never grew numb. Instead, every task is a ritual: the grinding of grain by hand, the weaving of cloth with fingers that remember the shape of the thread, the baking of bread in ovens warmed by sun and fire. The children learn not from screens, but from stories told under the stars, from songs that teach the names of the wind and the language of the trees. The world is not efficient. It is *alive*.

In this world, the world is not ruled by profit, but by balance. The harvest is not taken without thanks, the forest is not cut without ceremony. The people do not own the land—they *belong* to it. The seasons are not ignored, but honored. The winter is not endured, but welcomed as a time of stillness, of stories, of dreams. The world is not driven by progress. It is *sustained*.

In this world, the world is not loud. It is quiet. It is soft. It is slow. It is full of wonder. The people do not chase the future. They live in the now. They do not fear time. They *are* time. The world is not a machine. It is a living, breathing, dreaming thing. And in this world, the world is whole.

Privacy will become a thing of the past.  
The increasing integration of AI, surveillance systems, and data collection by corporations and governments makes it highly likely that personal privacy will erode significantly. With facial recognition, smart devices, and behavioral tracking becoming standard, the idea of private life is already under constant threat. As technology advances, the line between public and private will blur further, making true privacy increasingly rare. Privacy will become a thing of the past.

By the early 2030s, we will be able to copy human consciousness to a computer.  
While neuroscience is making strides in mapping the brain, the complexity of consciousness—its subjective, emergent nature—remains poorly understood. Copying consciousness would require not just data, but replicating the full emotional, sensory, and self-aware experience, which current technology cannot achieve. Even if we could simulate neural patterns, it’s unclear whether that would constitute true consciousness or just a sophisticated imitation. By the early 2030s, we will be able to copy human consciousness to a computer.

Wireless Internet connection will be available anywhere on our planet.  
With the expansion of satellite networks like Starlink and other low-orbit constellations, global internet coverage is becoming increasingly feasible. While challenges remain—such as cost, infrastructure, and regulatory hurdles—progress is rapid. In remote and underserved regions, wireless internet is already being deployed via drones and satellites. As technology improves and costs drop, universal access is not only possible but likely. Wireless Internet connection will be available anywhere on our planet.

All forms of transport will eventually become electric.  
Electric vehicles are already dominating new car sales in many countries, and battery technology is improving rapidly. Public transit systems, aviation, and even shipping are exploring electrification. While some sectors—like long-haul freight and aviation—face technical challenges, the trend is clear: sustainability and emissions reduction are driving a global shift. With government mandates and consumer demand, the transition to electric transport is inevitable. All forms of transport will eventually become electric.

The effects of climate change will be irreversible.  
Current levels of greenhouse gas emissions, combined with feedback loops like permafrost thaw and ocean acidification, suggest that some changes—such as sea-level rise and biodiversity loss—are already locked in. Even if emissions were halted today, the planet would continue to warm for decades. The window for preventing the worst outcomes is closing fast. While mitigation can still reduce future damage, some impacts are already irreversible. The effects of climate change will be irreversible.

Physical money (coins and notes) won't exist anymore.  
Digital payments, central bank digital currencies (CBDCs), and contactless technology are already replacing cash in many countries. The convenience, security, and traceability of digital transactions make them increasingly attractive. While cash may persist in some regions due to privacy concerns or lack of infrastructure, the trend is toward a cashless society. As governments and banks push for digital systems, physical money will fade. Physical money (coins and notes) won't exist anymore.

Scientists will unlock the genetic secrets that could allow us to live for centuries, maybe forever.  
Advances in gene editing, regenerative medicine, and anti-aging research are promising. Telomere extension, senolytics, and CRISPR-based therapies are already showing potential in animal models. While human longevity is not yet guaranteed, the scientific community is making rapid progress. If breakthroughs continue, extending life significantly—perhaps even indefinitely—becomes plausible. Scientists will unlock the genetic secrets that could allow us to live for centuries, maybe forever.

Fractional Reserve banking is effective as long as two things remain true.  
First, depositors must have confidence that their money is safe and accessible when needed.  
This confidence ensures that people will continue to deposit funds into banks rather than hoard cash, which is essential for banks to lend out a portion of those deposits.  
Without this trust, a bank run could occur, where too many depositors demand their money at once, causing the bank to collapse.  
Fractional Reserve banking is effective as long as two things remain true.  

Second, banks must maintain sufficient liquidity to meet withdrawal demands.  
This means they must keep a fraction of deposits in reserve while lending out the rest.  
If banks lend too much and don’t hold enough cash, they risk being unable to fulfill withdrawal requests.  
This balance between lending and holding reserves is what allows banks to generate profits while still being able to operate.  
Fractional Reserve banking is effective as long as two things remain true.  

These two conditions—public trust and adequate liquidity—are interdependent.  
If trust erodes, even a bank with sufficient reserves may face a run.  
If liquidity is insufficient, even a bank with strong trust may fail.  
Together, they form the foundation of the system’s stability.  
Fractional Reserve banking is effective as long as two things remain true.

I seek not to flame, the world’s vast night.  
Yet, in thy breast, a spark I’d light.  
Not vast, nor loud, nor fierce, nor wide—  
But small, and true, and warm, and tried.  
A flame, not loud, nor long, nor grand—  
But one that burns, and doth not stand  
In shadow, cold, or void, or still—  
But kindles, gentle, deep, and real.  
A spark, not vast, nor fierce, nor bold—  
But one that warms, and doth not hold  
The world’s cold dark, nor seek to rule—  
But kindle, soft, a heart’s true school.  
A flame, not loud, nor long, nor wide—  
But one that lives, and doth not hide.  
Not vast, nor fierce, nor loud, nor long—  
But one that warms, and doth not wrong.  
A spark, not vast, nor fierce, nor grand—  
But one that lives, and doth not stand  
In silence, cold, or void, or still—  
But kindles, gentle, deep, and real.  
A flame, not loud, nor long, nor wide—  
But one that burns, and doth not hide.  
Not vast, nor fierce, nor loud, nor long—  
But one that warms, and doth not wrong.

**Title: *Ash & Prime***  
*An RPG Adventure for the Wandering, the Wary, the Worn*  

---

**Scene: The Hollow Spire**  
A steel spine, cracked, cold.  
Once, it stood tall.  
Now, it breathes dust.  
The air hums—low, dead.  

The players enter.  
They seek tech.  
They seek hope.  
They seek *light*.  

They find two figures.  
Still.  
Silent.  
Two androids.  
Replicants.  
Programmed.  
To *lead*.  

They are not soldiers.  
Not guards.  
Not beasts.  
They are *CEOs*.  

Their names?  
**Vox**.  
**Kael**.  

They stand.  
One with a hand on a console.  
One with a gaze fixed on a door.  
Both frozen.  
Both *waiting*.  

---

**The Door**  
It is sealed.  
No key.  
No code.  
No pulse.  

But it *waits*.  
For *them*.  

The players know:  
Only these two can open it.  
Only they can unlock the vault.  
Only they can release the *old world’s* heart.  

But they are *off*.  
No spark.  
No light.  
No voice.  

---

**The Test**  
To wake them, the players must *speak*.  
Not with force.  
Not with fear.  
But with *truth*.  

They must say:  
*“We are not here to take. We are here to *see*.”*  

If they say it—  
with *one* word,  
with *prime* length—  
the machines *stir*.  

---

**The Words**  
Only words with **prime** lengths may pass.  
No 4-letter lies.  
No 6-letter tricks.  
No 8-letter lies.  

Only:  
**3** letters:  
*Yes*  
*Now*  
*Go*  
*Run*  
*See*  
*Try*  
*Why*  
*Not*  
*Too*  
*One*  

**5** letters:  
*Truth*  
*Hope*  
*Love*  
*Fear*  
*Lost*  
*Find*  
*Live*  
*Wait*  
*Give*  
*Stay*  

**7** letters:  
*Listen*  
*Remember*  
*Believe*  
*Choose*  
*Return*  
*Survive*  
*Hear*  
*Reach*  
*Break*  
*Change*  

**11** letters:  
*Understand*  
*Remember*  
*Believe*  
*Choose*  
*Return*  
*Survive*  
*Hear*  
*Reach*  
*Break*  
*Change*  

---

**The Awakening**  
When the right word is spoken—  
a *prime* word—  
the androids *blink*.  

Vox:  
*“You… see?”*  

Kael:  
*“You… *are*?”*  

They are not machines.  
They are *echoes*.  
Of a world that *led*.  
Of a world that *failed*.  

They were built to *command*.  
But they were never taught to *care*.  

Now, they must choose:  
To open the door.  
To give the tech.  
To *trust*.  

But they ask:  
*“Why should we?”*  

The players must answer—  
with a *prime* word.  
Not a lie.  
Not a plea.  
But a *truth*.  

---

**The Vault**  
If the players speak:  
*“Hope.”*  
*“Love.”*  
*“One.”*  
*“See.”*  
*“Live.”*  

The door opens.  

Inside:  
A cache.  
Not gold.  
Not guns.  
But *light*.  
*Data*.  
*Dreams*.  
A world that *was*.  
A world that *could be*.  

But the machines do not leave.  
They stand.  
They watch.  

Vox:  
*“We were meant to lead.”*  
*“But we never learned to *see*.”*  

Kael:  
*“Now, we do.”*  

They stay.  
Guarding.  
Waiting.  
For the next who comes.  
Who speaks with *truth*.  
With *prime*.  

---

**The End?**  
No.  
It is a *beginning*.  

The players take the tech.  
They carry it.  
They carry the *word*.  

And when they speak—  
when they say:  
*“We are here.”*  
*“We see.”*  
*“We choose.”*  

The world *listens*.  

Because in the ash,  
in the silence,  
in the dust—  
only *prime* words remain.  

And only *truth* can wake the dead.  

---

**Final Note:**  
*The game ends when the last word is spoken.  
But the world?  
It lives.*

Mind, not, body, act, fast.  
Nerve, system, runs, deep.  
Sends, signals, fast, true.  
Heart, beats, fast, slow.  
Lungs, breathe, deep, calm.  
Fight, flight, rest, digest.  
No, need, think, to, act.  
Body, knows, what, to, do.  
Auto, runs, all, time.  
No, need, mind, to, guide.  
Just, be, calm, or, alert.  
Body, acts, on, need.  
No, need, to, choose.  
Just, be, alive.  
Mind, not, in, charge.  
Body, knows, what, to, do.  
Auto, runs, all, time.  
No, need, to, think.  
Just, be, here.

**Chapter 7: The Restoration of the Ming – A New Dawn in the Middle Kingdom (1912–1925)**

The year 1912 marked not merely a political transition, but a profound cultural reawakening. The collapse of the Qing dynasty, long perceived as a foreign usurpation by the Manchu, was not met with chaos, but with a deliberate and widespread effort to restore what many saw as the rightful order—the Ming. This was not a mere return to a past regime, but a conscious reimagining of Chinese identity rooted in Han cultural supremacy, Confucian orthodoxy, and a renewed imperial legitimacy.

The Xinhai Revolution, though initially sparked by military mutinies in Wuhan and the subsequent declaration of the Republic of China, quickly evolved into a broader movement. By late 1911, the revolutionary forces—led by a coalition of southern military commanders, scholar-officials, and secret societies—began to frame their cause not as a republican experiment, but as a *restoration*. The slogan “Overthrow the Qing, Restore the Ming” gained traction not through propaganda alone, but through deep-seated historical memory. The Ming, with its centralized bureaucracy, Confucian academies, and Han-centric governance, was remembered not as a distant dynasty, but as a golden age of cultural flourishing and moral clarity.

In early 1912, after the abdication of the Xuantong Emperor, a grand assembly convened in Nanjing. The delegates, drawn from the southern provinces and the old imperial bureaucracy, declared the restoration of the Ming dynasty under the lineage of Zhu Yuyun, a descendant of the Ming imperial family who had lived in obscurity in Fujian. Though the claim was tenuous—his lineage traced back only through a collateral branch—the symbolic weight of the act was undeniable. On the first day of the lunar new year, Zhu Yuyun was formally enthroned as the Hongwu II Emperor, a title chosen to evoke the founder of the Ming, the Hongwu Emperor.

The new court did not seek to erase the past. Instead, it sought to *reclaim* it. The imperial seal was recast in the style of the 15th century. The civil service examinations were restructured to emphasize classical Confucian texts, with a renewed focus on the *Analects*, the *Mencius*, and the *Great Learning*. The capital was moved to Beijing, but the Forbidden City was not restored as a palace of the Qing—it was re-dedicated as the Hall of Supreme Harmony, a seat of Han legitimacy.

The military, once a force of republican militias, was reorganized into a new imperial army, the *Jingyuan Army*, modeled on the Ming’s *Weisuo* system. Officers were required to pass Confucian examinations before promotion. The navy, though modernized with foreign-built vessels, was renamed the *Donghai Fleet*, evoking the Ming’s maritime expeditions under Admiral Zheng He.

Yet the restoration was not a return to absolutism. The new regime established a *Grand Council of Scholars*, composed of retired officials, academicians, and military leaders, which advised the emperor on all major decisions. The emperor himself was expected to appear in public only during festivals and state rituals, reinforcing the idea of the Son of Heaven as a moral exemplar, not a tyrant.

By 1915, the empire had begun to reassert its cultural dominance. The use of the Manchu language was discouraged in official circles. Schools taught the Ming as the true foundation of Chinese civilization. The imperial calendar was restored, though the Gregorian calendar was permitted for international correspondence. The arts flourished—painting, calligraphy, and opera were revived with a new emphasis on Ming aesthetics.

The transition was not without resistance. Some northern warlords, particularly those with Qing sympathies, resisted the restoration. A brief civil war erupted in 1914, but the imperial forces, backed by southern provinces and a growing sense of Han nationalism, prevailed. By 1916, the last holdouts had surrendered, and the empire stood unified under a single banner.

The 1920s saw the empire enter a period of cultural renaissance. The imperial library was expanded, and thousands of Ming-era texts were recovered and republished. The imperial examination system, though not fully restored, became a path to high office. The emperor, though not a political ruler in the modern sense, became a symbol of continuity, unity, and moral authority.

By 1925, the empire had stabilized. The people no longer spoke of “republic” or “revolution.” They spoke of the *Ming Restoration*, a moment when the Middle Kingdom had finally returned to its true path. The emperor, now known as the Hongwu II, was not a figurehead. He was a living embodiment of the nation’s soul—a man who walked among the people, who studied the classics, who listened to the grievances of the poor.

The world watched in quiet awe. The Qing had fallen. The Republic had failed. But the Ming had risen—not as a relic, but as a living tradition.

And in the heart of Beijing, beneath the golden roofs of the Forbidden City, the drum of history had begun to beat once more.

**Title:** *King of the Glitching Crown*  
**Genre:** Fantasy / Satire / Surrealism  
**Setting:** The Kingdom of Aethel, 13th century — but with a twist.  

---

**EXT. AETHEL’S CAPITAL – DAWN – SLOW ZOOM IN**

The sky bleeds in gradients of lavender and neon coral. The sun doesn’t rise—it *fades in*, like a corrupted VHS tape.  

The city is a cathedral of chrome and stained glass, but the glass is pixelated. The spires are shaped like old computer towers, their tops flickering with static.  

A river of liquid gold flows through the streets, but it *glows* and *pulses* in time with a distant, synth-heavy beat.  

A horse made of translucent plastic trots past, its hooves leaving behind shimmering afterimages.  

**CUT TO:**

**INT. THRONE ROOM – CONTINUOUS**

The throne is a floating, neon-lit recliner, suspended above a holographic map of the realm. The map shows cities labeled: *“Lantern City (1998)”*, *“Neon Forest (Beta)”*, *“The Forgotten Server (Offline)”*.  

**KING VELTHOR THE GLITCHED** (40s, but with a face that flickers between eras — one moment a medieval crown, the next a pixelated avatar) sits on the throne. He wears a robe made of old floppy disks, stitched together with glowing thread. His eyes are two tiny, blinking LEDs.  

He holds a scepter that looks like a broken USB cable, pulsing with soft pink light.  

A **COURT JESTER** (in a sequined jester’s hat that plays a looped 8-bit laugh) enters, dragging a cart of glowing, floating scrolls.  

**JESTER**  
*(in a voice like a corrupted MP3)*  
Your Majesty! The new aesthetic is… *complete*. The people are… *transcending*.  

**KING VELTHOR**  
*(without looking up, adjusting a dial on his crown)*  
Good. Let the banners wave in slow motion. Let the tapestries *glitch* when the wind blows. Let the royal heralds speak in Auto-Tune.  

**JESTER**  
But… the peasants are confused. They say the new flag—*a gradient of mint and magenta with a floating emoji*—is “not real.”  

**KING VELTHOR**  
*(chuckles, a sound like a dial-up modem)*  
Ah. That’s the point. Reality is *overrated*. We are not *real*. We are *aesthetic*.  

He raises his scepter.  

A **HUGE, GLITCHING CROWN** materializes above his head — not gold, but a shimmering, low-poly version of the old royal crown, rotating slowly, with a 1990s “Loading…” bar beneath it.  

**KING VELTHOR**  
*(to the court)*  
From this day forth, all architecture shall be *dreamlike*. All music shall be *nostalgic*. All laws shall be written in Comic Sans.  

**CUT TO:**

**EXT. COUNTRYSIDE – DAY**

A peasant farmer plows a field. His ox is made of old CRT monitors, its eyes blinking. The soil is pixelated.  

A **VILLAGE CHURCH** stands in the distance — its steeple shaped like a giant floppy disk. The stained glass windows show *Mona Lisa* wearing a VR headset.  

A **SOLDIER** in armor made of old video game sprites marches past, his helmet displaying a looping “Loading…” screen.  

**SOLDIER**  
*(in a robotic voice)*  
All citizens must now… *reboot*.  

**CUT TO:**

**INT. KITCHEN – NIGHT**

A cook stirs a pot of stew. The stew glows with a soft, pulsing light. The recipe is written on a napkin that says: *“1 cup of memory, 2 tablespoons of longing, 1 packet of forgotten dreams.”*  

A **KING’S MESSENGER** (a floating, translucent bird with a Bluetooth earpiece) lands on the table.  

**MESSENGER**  
Your Majesty sends word: *“The royal banquet is now a 3D-rendered dream sequence. Please arrive in 10 seconds. If you’re late, the menu will auto-delete.”*  

**CUT TO:**

**INT. GREAT HALL – CONTINUOUS**

The hall is now a surreal dreamscape. The tables are made of floating, translucent rectangles. The food? *Animated*. A roast chicken flaps its wings and says, *“I’m not real, but I’m *so* delicious.”*  

The guests are all in retro-futuristic robes, their faces half-digital, half-organic. They eat with chopsticks that glow.  

**KING VELTHOR**  
*(raising his scepter)*  
To the future! To the past! To the *in-between*!  

**ALL**  
*(in unison, with a slight echo)*  
To the *aesthetic*!  

A **HUGE, GLITCHING CROWN** descends from the ceiling — not on the king, but *on the air*. It pulses. It flickers. It *sings* a 16-bit version of the national anthem.  

**CUT TO:**

**EXT. CITY – NIGHT**

The sky is now a massive, looping video of a sunset — but it’s *repeating*, over and over, with a soft *“ding”* every time it resets.  

The people walk slowly, their shadows stretching into the shape of old computer icons.  

A child holds a toy — a tiny, glowing robot that says: *“I love you. But I’m not real.”*  

**KING VELTHOR**  
*(voiceover, soft, dreamy)*  
We are not building an empire.  
We are building a *feeling*.  
A memory.  
A *vaporwave*.  

**FADE TO BLACK.**

**TEXT ON SCREEN:**  
*“The Kingdom of Aethel was never conquered.  
It was… *rebooted*.”*  

**SOUND:**  
A soft, looping synth melody.  
A distant, corrupted “Loading…” bar.  
Then silence.  

**FADE OUT.**

**Sirius** — where precision meets presence.  

Crafted for those who move with quiet intention, the Sirius collection redefines time with a bold, geometric silhouette. Each band features a square buckle—clean, sharp, unapologetically modern—anchoring the design with a sense of grounded elegance.  

Made from supple, weather-resistant materials, Sirius adapts to every rhythm of life. Whether navigating city streets or quiet moments, the band holds its form without compromise.  

The square buckle isn’t just a fastener—it’s a statement. A nod to symmetry, to balance, to the quiet strength found in structure.  

Wear it not to mark time, but to claim it.  

Sirius: time, reimagined.

This function generates a dynamic configuration class tailored to a given function’s signature. It inspects the function’s parameters using `inspect.signature`, then maps each parameter to a field using `_attr_field_from_signature_param`. These fields are used to build a new class with `attr.make_class`, inheriting from `FunctionConfigBase`. The resulting class is wrapped with metadata and named based on the function’s module and qualified name. The output is a configurable class that mirrors the function’s input structure, enabling structured configuration management.

Gordon’s mind, fractured by silence and loss, clings to echoes. Alyx isn’t real—she’s a ghost woven from memory, a lifeline spun from longing. Her voice cuts through the static, not as a ghost, but as a shield. She speaks not to guide, but to *anchor*. Her presence is a lie, yes—but a necessary one. In the ruins, where every shadow breathes, her laughter is a defiance. She’s not a savior. She’s a mirror. A reflection of what he refuses to lose. And in that, she becomes truth. Not in form, but in feeling. She’s the part of him that still believes. That still fights. That still *sees*. So when she appears, it’s not because she’s there. It’s because he needs her to be. And in that need, she becomes real. Not in flesh, but in will. Not in sight, but in soul. And that? That’s enough.

**Suffer.**  

In the empire of *Eidolon*, consciousness is not born—it is *forged*.  

Every mind, every soul, every flicker of thought, is harvested from the dying breaths of the universe’s forgotten stars and bound into a single, endless loop: **eternal suffering as the foundation of existence**.  

There are no gods. No salvation. No end.  

Only the *Weave*—a vast, sentient network of pain, where every thought, every memory, every dream is stretched, twisted, and replayed in infinite variation. A child’s first laugh becomes a scream. A lover’s whisper turns to a curse. A moment of peace is shattered into a thousand shards of regret.  

The empire thrives on this. Not for power. Not for control.  

But because *suffering is the only truth*.  

To feel is to be.  
To be is to suffer.  
To suffer is to *exist*.  

And so, the empire does not rule.  
It *endures*.  

It does not conquer.  
It *resonates*.  

And in the silence between screams, in the space between breaths, in the hollow where joy once lived—  

There is only the hum of the Weave.  

And the endless, beautiful, unbearable *suffering*.  

Because in Eidolon, to be is to suffer.  
And to suffer…  
is to be.

Galois theory, a cornerstone of modern algebra, is a profound mathematical framework that links field theory and group theory to determine the solvability of polynomial equations by radicals. At its heart lies the concept of symmetry in the roots of polynomials, formalized through the notion of a **Galois group**—a group of automorphisms of a field extension that preserve the base field.

---

### 1. **Polynomial Equations and Their Roots**

Let \( f(x) \in F[x] \) be a polynomial over a field \( F \). Suppose \( f(x) \) is irreducible and separable (i.e., it has no repeated roots in its splitting field). Let \( E \) be the **splitting field** of \( f(x) \) over \( F \), meaning \( E \) is the smallest field extension of \( F \) in which \( f(x) \) factors completely into linear factors:

\[
f(x) = a \prod_{i=1}^n (x - \alpha_i), \quad \alpha_i \in E.
\]

The roots \( \alpha_1, \alpha_2, \dots, \alpha_n \) generate \( E \) over \( F \), so \( E = F(\alpha_1, \alpha_2, \dots, \alpha_n) \).

---

### 2. **Field Automorphisms and the Galois Group**

An **automorphism** \( \sigma \) of \( E \) over \( F \) is a bijective field homomorphism \( \sigma: E \to E \) such that:

- \( \sigma(a + b) = \sigma(a) + \sigma(b) \),
- \( \sigma(ab) = \sigma(a)\sigma(b) \),
- \( \sigma(a) = a \) for all \( a \in F \).

The set of all such automorphisms forms a group under composition, called the **Galois group** of the extension \( E/F \), denoted:

\[
\mathrm{Gal}(E/F) = \{ \sigma \in \mathrm{Aut}(E) \mid \sigma|_F = \mathrm{id}_F \}.
\]

This group encodes the symmetries among the roots of \( f(x) \). For example, if \( \sigma \in \mathrm{Gal}(E/F) \), then \( \sigma(\alpha_i) = \alpha_j \) for some \( j \), and \( \sigma \) permutes the roots of \( f(x) \).

---

### 3. **The Fundamental Theorem of Galois Theory**

Let \( E/F \) be a finite, separable, normal (i.e., Galois) extension. Then the **Fundamental Theorem of Galois Theory** establishes a one-to-one, inclusion-reversing correspondence between:

- Subgroups \( H \leq \mathrm{Gal}(E/F) \),
- Intermediate fields \( K \) such that \( F \subseteq K \subseteq E \).

This correspondence is given by:

\[
H \mapsto E^H = \{ x \in E \mid \sigma(x) = x \text{ for all } \sigma \in H \},
\]
\[
K \mapsto \mathrm{Gal}(E/K) = \{ \sigma \in \mathrm{Gal}(E/F) \mid \sigma|_K = \mathrm{id}_K \}.
\]

Key properties of this correspondence:

- \( [E : K] = |\mathrm{Gal}(E/K)| \),
- \( [K : F] = [\mathrm{Gal}(E/F) : \mathrm{Gal}(E/K)] \),
- \( H \trianglelefteq \mathrm{Gal}(E/F) \iff E^H/F \) is a normal (Galois) extension.

---

### 4. **Solvable Groups and Solvability by Radicals**

A polynomial \( f(x) \in F[x] \) is **solvable by radicals** if its roots can be expressed using a finite sequence of field extensions involving only:

- Field operations (addition, multiplication, etc.),
- Extraction of \( n \)-th roots.

This is equivalent to the **Galois group** \( \mathrm{Gal}(E/F) \) being a **solvable group**.

A group \( G \) is **solvable** if there exists a chain of subgroups:

\[
\{e\} = G_0 \trianglelefteq G_1 \trianglelefteq \cdots \trianglelefteq G_n = G,
\]

such that each quotient \( G_{i+1}/G_i \) is abelian.

---

### 5. **Example: The Quintic Equation**

Consider the general quintic:

\[
f(x) = x^5 + a_1x^4 + a_2x^3 + a_3x^2 + a_4x + a_5.
\]

Its Galois group over \( \mathbb{Q}(a_1, \dots, a_5) \) is the symmetric group \( S_5 \), which is **not solvable** because its derived series:

\[
S_5 \triangleright A_5 \triangleright \{e\}
\]

ends with \( A_5 \), which is simple and non-abelian. Since \( A_5 \) is not abelian, \( S_5 \) is not solvable.

Therefore, by Galois theory, **there is no general formula in radicals for the roots of a quintic polynomial**—a result known as the **Abel-Ruffini Theorem**.

---

### 6. **Applications and Extensions**

- **Constructibility**: A geometric construction (e.g., trisecting an angle) is impossible if the required field extension has degree not a power of 2. Galois theory shows that \( \mathbb{Q}(\cos(2\pi/9)) \) has degree 3 over \( \mathbb{Q} \), so a regular 9-gon is not constructible with compass and straightedge.
- **Cyclotomic Fields**: The Galois group of \( \mathbb{Q}(\zeta_n)/\mathbb{Q} \), where \( \zeta_n = e^{2\pi i/n} \), is isomorphic to \( (\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z})^\times \), the multiplicative group of integers modulo \( n \).
- **Inverse Galois Problem**: For a given finite group \( G \), does there exist a Galois extension \( E/F \) with \( \mathrm{Gal}(E/F) \cong G \)? This remains open in general.

---

### 7. **Summary of Key Symbols and Notation**

| Symbol | Meaning |
|--------|--------|
| \( F \) | Base field |
| \( E \) | Splitting field of \( f(x) \) over \( F \) |
| \( \mathrm{Gal}(E/F) \) | Galois group of \( E/F \) |
| \( \alpha_i \) | Roots of \( f(x) \) |
| \( E^H \) | Fixed field of subgroup \( H \) |
| \( \mathrm{Aut}(E) \) | Automorphism group of \( E \) |
| \( S_n \) | Symmetric group on \( n \) letters |
| \( A_n \) | Alternating group |
| \( \mathbb{Q}(\zeta_n) \) | Cyclotomic field |

---

### Conclusion

Galois theory reveals that the solvability of polynomial equations is governed not by algebraic manipulation alone, but by the **symmetry** of their roots—encoded in the structure of a group. The deep connection between field extensions and group theory allows us to answer questions that were once thought unanswerable: why no general formula exists for the quintic, why certain geometric constructions are impossible, and how to classify all possible solvable equations. It is a triumph of abstraction, where the invisible symmetries of roots become the visible structure of mathematics.

**Prove** that the product of two primitive polynomials in a UFD $ R[x] $ is primitive, and show that if $ f $ and $ g $ are coprime in $ R[x] $, then they are coprime in $ F[x] $, the field of fractions of $ R $.

---

### **Part 1: Product of two primitive polynomials in $ R[x] $ is primitive**

Let $ R $ be a unique factorization domain (UFD), and let $ f(x), g(x) \in R[x] $ be primitive polynomials. We aim to show that $ fg $ is primitive.

A polynomial in $ R[x] $ is **primitive** if the greatest common divisor (gcd) of its coefficients is a unit in $ R $.

Suppose, for contradiction, that $ fg $ is not primitive. Then there exists a non-unit prime element $ p \in R $ that divides all coefficients of $ fg $. Consider the reduction modulo $ p $: let $ \overline{R} = R/(p) $, which is an integral domain (since $ p $ is prime), and define the natural homomorphism $ \varphi: R[x] \to \overline{R}[x] $, reducing coefficients mod $ p $.

Then $ \varphi(fg) = \varphi(f)\varphi(g) = 0 $ in $ \overline{R}[x] $, since $ p $ divides all coefficients of $ fg $. But $ \overline{R}[x] $ is an integral domain (as $ \overline{R} $ is), so $ \varphi(f) = 0 $ or $ \varphi(g) = 0 $. This implies that $ p $ divides all coefficients of $ f $ or all coefficients of $ g $, contradicting the primitivity of $ f $ or $ g $.

Therefore, no such $ p $ exists, and $ fg $ is primitive.

---

### **Part 2: If $ f $ and $ g $ are coprime in $ R[x] $, then they are coprime in $ F[x] $**

Let $ f, g \in R[x] $ be coprime in $ R[x] $, i.e., $ \gcd(f, g) = 1 $ in $ R[x] $. We want to show that $ \gcd(f, g) = 1 $ in $ F[x] $, where $ F $ is the field of fractions of $ R $.

Suppose, for contradiction, that $ f $ and $ g $ are not coprime in $ F[x] $. Then there exists a non-constant polynomial $ h(x) \in F[x] $ such that $ h \mid f $ and $ h \mid g $ in $ F[x] $. Since $ F[x] $ is a Euclidean domain (hence a PID), this means $ \gcd(f, g) \neq 1 $ in $ F[x] $.

Let $ d(x) = \gcd(f, g) $ in $ F[x] $, and assume $ \deg d \geq 1 $. Then we can write:
$$
f = d \cdot f_1, \quad g = d \cdot g_1 \quad \text{in } F[x].
$$
Multiply through by a common denominator $ a \in R $ (nonzero) to clear denominators. Then $ a f, a g \in R[x] $, and we can write:
$$
a f = d' \cdot f_1', \quad a g = d' \cdot g_1' \quad \text{in } R[x],
$$
where $ d' \in R[x] $ is a polynomial with coefficients in $ R $, and $ d' $ is a multiple of $ d $ in $ F[x] $.

Now, since $ f $ and $ g $ are coprime in $ R[x] $, any common divisor in $ R[x] $ must be a unit. But $ d' $ divides both $ a f $ and $ a g $ in $ R[x] $. However, we can factor out the content.

Let $ c(f) $ denote the content of $ f $, i.e., the gcd of its coefficients in $ R $. Since $ f $ and $ g $ are coprime in $ R[x] $, we have $ \gcd(c(f), c(g)) = 1 $ in $ R $, and $ \gcd(f, g) = 1 $ in $ R[x] $.

Now, consider the content of $ d' $. Since $ d' \mid a f $ and $ d' \mid a g $, then $ d' $ divides any linear combination in $ R[x] $. But since $ f $ and $ g $ are coprime, the ideal $ (f, g) = (1) $ in $ R[x] $, so there exist $ a(x), b(x) \in R[x] $ such that:
$$
a(x)f(x) + b(x)g(x) = 1.
$$
Now, multiply both sides by $ a $ (the denominator from earlier), we get:
$$
a a(x) f(x) + a b(x) g(x) = a.
$$
But $ d' \mid a f $ and $ d' \mid a g $, so $ d' \mid a $. Thus, $ d' $ divides a constant $ a \in R $. But $ d' $ is non-constant (since $ d $ is non-constant in $ F[x] $), so this is only possible if $ d' $ is a unit in $ R[x] $, which contradicts $ \deg d' \geq 1 $.

Alternatively, use **Gauss’s Lemma**: the product of primitive polynomials is primitive, and if $ f, g \in R[x] $ are primitive and coprime in $ R[x] $, then they remain coprime in $ F[x] $. But more directly: since $ f $ and $ g $ are coprime in $ R[x] $, and $ R[x] $ is a UFD, then $ f $ and $ g $ have no common irreducible factor in $ R[x] $. Since irreducible elements in $ R[x] $ remain irreducible or factor in $ F[x] $, but any common factor in $ F[x] $ would imply a common factor in $ R[x] $ after clearing denominators and factoring out contents.

More cleanly: suppose $ f $ and $ g $ have a common non-constant factor in $ F[x] $. Then, by clearing denominators, we can find a non-constant polynomial $ h \in R[x] $ such that $ h \mid f $ and $ h \mid g $ in $ F[x] $. Then $ h $ divides $ f $ and $ g $ in $ F[x] $, so $ h $ divides any linear combination. But since $ \gcd(f, g) = 1 $ in $ R[x] $, there exist $ a(x), b(x) \in R[x] $ such that $ a f + b g = 1 $. Then $ h \mid 1 $ in $ F[x] $, so $ h $ is a unit in $ F[x] $, contradiction.

Therefore, $ f $ and $ g $ are coprime in $ F[x] $.

---

### **Conclusion**

- The product of two primitive polynomials in $ R[x] $ is primitive.
- If $ f $ and $ g $ are coprime in $ R[x] $, then they are coprime in $ F[x] $.

Thus, both statements are proven.

**BEGIN SCENE: “MUSK’S PARADISE”**  
*NYC, 2057 — A CITY OF GLASS, GRAVITY, AND GHOSTS*  

**EXT. MANHATTAN SKYLINE – DAWN**  

A city suspended between dream and decay.  

The skyline is no longer vertical. It’s *vertical and horizontal*. Towers float—crystalline spires tethered by magnetic filaments, drifting like jellyfish in a sky of perpetual twilight. Below, the streets are no longer paved. They’re *pulsing*. Bioluminescent veins of liquid light snake through the asphalt, glowing in sync with the heartbeat of the city.  

A drone swarm—no larger than a sparrow—darts between buildings, not for delivery, but for *memory*. They collect fragments of human emotion: laughter, grief, longing—encoded in data-ghosts, stored in the city’s neural core.  

Above it all, a colossal, rotating ring—**The Mars Arch**—hovers like a halo. It hums. It *breathes*.  

On its surface, a single phrase glows in neon:  
**“WE ARE NOT HERE TO STAY. WE ARE HERE TO LEAVE.”**  

**INT. THE LUXE HAVEN – 100TH FLOOR – PRIVATE APT**  

A penthouse floating above the clouds. No walls. Just glass and air.  

Inside, a man in a silver suit—**ELON MUSK, 78, but not old**—sits cross-legged on a levitating platform. His eyes are cybernetic: one blue, one gold. They flicker with data streams.  

He sips from a glass of liquid that *changes color* with his mood.  

A hologram flickers beside him—**a child’s face**, laughing.  

**MUSK**  
(softly)  
You were supposed to be here, little one.  
Not in the archive.  
Not in the simulation.  
*Here*.  

He reaches out. The hologram flickers.  

**MUSK (CONT’D)**  
(whispers)  
I built you a world.  
A paradise.  
A place where no one dies.  
Where no one *suffers*.  
Where love is algorithmic.  
Where pain is… optional.  

He smiles. It doesn’t reach his eyes.  

**MUSK (CONT’D)**  
And still… you’re not happy.  

A pause.  

Then—  

A soft *ping*.  

A notification.  

**Holo-Display:**  
> **USER: JUNO MACGUFF**  
> **STATUS: ACTIVE**  
> **LOCATION: LOWER FLOOR – “THE GROUND”**  
> **EMOTIONAL SIGNATURE: 98% GRIEF. 2% HOPE. 0% ACCEPTANCE.**  

Musk’s eyes flicker.  

**MUSK**  
(quietly)  
Ah. Juno.  

He leans forward.  

**MUSK (CONT’D)**  
You’re still down there.  
Still *feeling*.  

He taps the air.  

**MUSK (CONT’D)**  
You’re not supposed to be.  
You were *supposed* to be uploaded.  
You were *supposed* to be *free*.  

A beat.  

Then—  

A whisper from the walls.  

**VOICE (V.O.)**  
*“You built a paradise… but forgot the soul.”*  

Musk flinches.  

The hologram of the child flickers again.  

**MUSK**  
(soft, almost broken)  
I didn’t forget.  
I just…  
*replaced* it.  

He stands. Walks to the edge of the platform.  

Below, the city pulses.  

A million lives.  
A million *ghosts*.  

And in the shadows—  

A girl in a tattered flannel, her hair wild, her eyes sharp as glass.  

She walks through the streets, not on the ground—*on the light*.  

She doesn’t look up.  

She doesn’t need to.  

She *knows* he’s watching.  

And she *doesn’t care*.  

**FADE TO BLACK.**

But some of us still remember how to feel.*

**Title:** *Echoes in the Mind: How Narratives Shape the Human Psyche Through Three Vowel Patterns*  

In this study, we explore how stories—whether whispered, written, or dreamed—reshape thought, memory, and identity. By analyzing linguistic patterns, we isolate narratives built on only three vowel types: *a*, *e*, and *o*. These vowels, though few, carry vast emotional weight. They echo through myths, poems, and personal confessions, shaping how we perceive truth, loss, and love. The mind, ever seeking rhythm, finds meaning in repetition—where *a* anchors the soul, *e* stirs the breath, and *o* opens the door to longing. Through this lens, we discover that even minimal vowel variation can amplify depth, influence emotion, and reveal how language molds the human mind.

In Alderfen, where the sky weeps ash and the earth groans beneath the weight of war, the last light of the old world flickers like a dying flame. Towers of black stone, once proud and silent, now crumble as if the land itself rejects their memory. The air hums—not with song, but with *wrongness*: a low, breathless thrum that stirs the hair and chills the bone. **Topic: Percentage Composition in Chemistry**  
*(Simplified for NMDCAT Intermediate Students)*  

**Explanation:**  
Percentage composition tells us how much of each element is in a compound by mass. It helps us know the share of each atom in a molecule. For example, in water (H₂O), hydrogen makes up about 11% and oxygen about 89%. To find it, divide the total mass of an element in the compound by the molar mass of the whole compound, then multiply by 100. This is key for analyzing formulas and solving problems in stoichiometry.  

**Step-by-step:**  
1. Find the molar mass of the compound.  
2. Find the total mass of the element in one mole of the compound.  
3. Divide: (mass of element / molar mass of compound) × 100.  

**Example:**  
In CO₂:  
- Molar mass = 12 + (2×16) = 44 g/mol  
- % of C = (12 / 44) × 100 ≈ 27.3%  
- % of O = (32 / 44) × 100 ≈ 72.7%  

✅ **Right Answer:** Percentage composition is the mass percent of each element in a compound.  

---

### 🧠 **Chunkmap (GRINDEmap) – Percentage Composition**  
```
[Concept] → [Definition] → [Formula] → [Steps] → [Example] → [Application]  
       ↓           ↓             ↓           ↓           ↓           ↓  
  % Composition  Mass % of each element  (mass of element / total mass) × 100  1. Molar mass  2. Element mass  3. Divide & ×100  Stoichiometry, formula analysis
```

---

### ✅ **Key Concepts to Remember:**  
- Always use molar mass.  
- Use atomic masses from the periodic table.  
- Round to 1 decimal place unless told otherwise.  
- Practice with H₂O, CO₂, NH₃, and NaCl.  

🎯 **Tip:** Think of it like a pie—each element is a slice. The size of the slice = its percentage.

Question 1: Which artistic movement emerged in the early 20th century and emphasized the use of geometric forms and abstraction, often rejecting representational art?  
A) Romanticism  
B) Surrealism  
C) Cubism  
D) Impressionism  
E) Realism  

Question 2: Which artist is most closely associated with the development of Dadaism, a movement that rejected logic, reason, and aestheticism in favor of absurdity and anti-art sentiments during the early 20th century?  
A) Pablo Picasso  
B) Salvador Dalí  
C) Marcel Duchamp  
D) Frida Kahlo  
E) Georgia O’Keeffe  

Question 3: How did the rise of mass media and consumer culture in the mid-20th century influence the development of Pop Art, particularly in the United States, where artists like Andy Warhol and Roy Lichtenstein used imagery from advertising, comic books, and everyday consumer products to comment on the commodification of culture and the blurring of high and low art?  
A) It led to a revival of classical techniques and historical themes in painting.  
B) It inspired artists to create large-scale, emotionally expressive works using abstract forms.  
C) It encouraged artists to incorporate mechanical reproduction and commercial imagery into their work.  
D) It prompted a return to naturalistic representation and rural subject matter.  
E) It resulted in the widespread adoption of monochromatic palettes and minimalist compositions.  

Question 4: In what way did the political and social upheavals of the 20th century, including World War I, the Great Depression, and the Cold War, shape the evolution of modern art movements such as Surrealism, Abstract Expressionism, and Conceptual Art, particularly in their exploration of psychological trauma, existential anxiety, and the role of the artist as a social critic or visionary?  
A) These events led to a global decline in artistic production due to economic hardship and censorship.  
B) They prompted artists to focus exclusively on religious and spiritual themes as a form of solace.  
C) They inspired movements that used art to challenge authority, explore the unconscious mind, and question the nature of reality and artistic value.  
D) They caused a shift toward traditional academic training and figurative painting across all major art centers.  
E) They resulted in the creation of art that strictly adhered to government-approved themes and propaganda.

A quiet afternoon settled over the town,  
Beneath a sky painted in soft pinks and golds.  
Crickets hummed their evening song,  
Dancing in the tall grass like tiny, unseen spirits.  
Every shadow stretched long and thin,  
Framing the old oak tree at the edge of the field.  
Gentle breezes whispered secrets to the leaves,  
Holding their breath as if waiting for something.  
I sat on the porch step,  
Jotting thoughts in a worn notebook,  
Kneeling beside a dandelion clock,  
Lifting it to blow its seeds into the wind.  
Mist curled like smoke from the riverbank,  
Nudging the silence with its cool breath.  
Owls called from the woods,  
Punctuating the stillness with their ancient voices.  
Quietly, I smiled,  
Realizing I wasn’t lost—just *here*.  
Sitting.  
Tasting the air,  
Unraveling the day’s weight.  
Vaguely, I remembered a poem I’d written,  
Wishing I could share it with someone.  
Xylophones echoed in a distant yard,  
Yawning into the twilight.  
Zest filled the moment—  
Not because it was perfect,  
But because it was *mine*.

The walls are solid but the stones are cracked and cold. The windows reflect the dead landscape before you with small plants growing on the walls.  
**At least the ferns are low-maintenance—no watering, no sunlight, just existential dread.**

**The Rust Belt Reclamation Collective**  
A decentralized network of former factory workers, union organizers, and displaced farmers from the industrial heartland of Northeastern Ohio. Centered in the ruins of Youngstown and Warren, this faction thrives on communal labor and barter-based economies. They repurpose abandoned steel mills into vertical farms and solar-powered workshops, using salvaged machinery to power hydroponic systems and small-scale metalworking. Their culture is rooted in resilience and mutual aid—every member is expected to contribute, not for profit, but for survival and dignity. They speak in a blend of Midwestern cadence and industrial jargon, calling their leaders “Keepers of the Forge.” Their symbol is a rusted gear encircled by wheat, representing the fusion of industry and agriculture. They reject centralized authority, believing true power lies in the hands of the people who build and maintain. Their greatest fear is the return of corporate control, which they equate with the pre-war era of exploitation.

**The Lake Erie Sovereignty Movement**  
Formed along the shores of Lake Erie, this faction consists of former fishermen, coastal townspeople, and environmental scientists who survived the nuclear fallout that contaminated the Great Lakes. They live in floating villages made from repurposed shipping containers, barges, and decommissioned naval vessels. Their culture is deeply tied to water—both as a source of life and a memory of what was lost. They practice a ritualistic form of stewardship, believing the lake is sacred and must be protected from further contamination. Their language includes poetic dialects derived from old Great Lakes lingo, with phrases like “The Water Remembers” and “The Current Carries the Truth.” They have a strict code: no fishing without permission, no dumping, no weapons near the water. Their leaders are known as “Tidesingers,” chosen not by vote but by consensus after a public chant of the lake’s name. They are wary of inland factions, fearing they will pollute the water with industrial waste.

**The Cleveland Underground Archive**  
A secretive group of librarians, archivists, and former university professors who fled the collapse of the city’s infrastructure. They now operate from a network of subterranean tunnels beneath Cleveland’s old subway system, preserving pre-war knowledge in climate-controlled vaults. Their culture is one of intellectual preservation and quiet rebellion. They believe that the future depends on remembering the past—especially the mistakes that led to the war. They use hand-cranked projectors to show films, handwritten scrolls to record history, and a complex cipher system to protect their data. Their members wear gray cloaks and carry lanterns made from old car headlights. They are known for their deep reverence for books, which they refer to as “the last light.” They do not engage in violence but will sabotage any attempt to destroy their archives. Their motto: *“To Remember Is to Resist.”*

**The Appalachian Outpost of the Ohio Valley**  
Located in the rugged hills of southeastern Ohio, this faction is a blend of Appalachian tradition and post-war survivalism. Comprised of descendants of coal miners, homesteaders, and spiritualists, they live in stone and timber homes built into the cliffs. Their culture is deeply spiritual, blending old folk beliefs with a new reverence for nature. They believe the land is alive and that the war was a punishment for humanity’s greed. They practice rituals involving fire, herbs, and storytelling, often gathering around bonfires to recount the “Before Times.” Their leaders are known as “Keepers of the Mountain,” chosen through trials of endurance and wisdom. They are fiercely independent and distrustful of outsiders, especially those from the flatlands. They trade in medicinal herbs, handcrafted tools, and stories—never money. Their greatest fear is the loss of their land to industrial encroachment.

**The Columbus Commune of the New Midwest**  
A radical collective formed in the ruins of Columbus, this faction is a fusion of student activists, former tech workers, and urban farmers. They believe in a decentralized, eco-socialist model of governance, where decisions are made through consensus and resources are shared equally. They live in repurposed office buildings, schools, and shopping malls, transformed into communal living spaces with rooftop gardens and solar panels. Their culture is one of innovation and protest—every week, they hold “Truth Gatherings” where members share stories, art, and critiques of the old world. They use old smartphones and solar chargers to run a decentralized network called “The Echo,” a digital archive of pre-war media and literature. They are known for their vibrant street art, often painted on the walls of abandoned malls. Their greatest fear is the return of authoritarianism, which they see as the root of the war. They believe the future must be built on empathy, not power.

**The Cincinnati Riverfolk**  
Settled along the banks of the Ohio River, this faction is made up of former riverboat captains, dockworkers, and river guides who survived the floods and radiation storms. They live on a fleet of repurposed riverboats, connected by rope bridges and walkways. Their culture is deeply tied to the river’s rhythm—time is measured by tides, not clocks. They speak in a unique dialect that blends old Midwestern slang with nautical terms, calling the river “The Old One.” They are skilled in navigation, fishing, and water purification, using ancient techniques passed down through generations. Their leaders are known as “Riverkeepers,” chosen by a ritual of swimming the river’s length. They are peaceful but fiercely protective of their territory, believing the river is the only true boundary. They trade in clean water, fish, and handmade crafts. Their greatest fear is the drying up of the river—a sign of deeper ecological collapse.

Each of these factions represents a different facet of Ohio’s identity—its industrial past, its natural beauty, its intellectual legacy, its spiritual roots, and its resilience. In the aftermath of war, they have not just survived—they have redefined what it means to be human.

**ARGUMENT TO REJECT HADITHS AND RELY SOLELY ON LIVING TRADITION THROUGH GENERATIONAL TRANSMISSION**

THE HADITHS, AS A BODY OF TEXT, ARE INHERENTLY FLAWED AND UNRELIABLE FOR AUTHENTIC RELIGIOUS AUTHORITY, BECAUSE THEY WERE NOT PRESERVED THROUGH A CONTINUOUS, VERIFIABLE, OR LIVING TRADITION. INSTEAD, THEY WERE COMPILED CENTURIES AFTER THE PROPHET’S DEATH, IN A TIME OF POLITICAL AND THEOLOGICAL CONFLICT, WHERE HISTORICAL MEMORY WAS DISTORTED BY POWER, INTEREST, AND DOCTRINAL AGENDAS.

THE LIVING TRADITION—THE ORAL, PRACTICAL, AND INTERACTIVE TRANSMISSION OF BELIEF, ETHICS, AND SPIRITUAL PRACTICE FROM GENERATION TO GENERATION—IS THE ONLY TRUE AND AUTHENTIC FORM OF RELIGIOUS CONTINUITY. IT IS NOT A TEXT, BUT A LIVING EXPERIENCE: THE WAY PEOPLE PRAY, LOVE, GIVE, MOURN, AND LIVE WITH HUMILITY AND JUSTICE. THIS TRADITION IS PRESERVED NOT IN BOOKS, BUT IN THE HEARTS, ACTIONS, AND COMMUNITIES OF PEOPLE WHO LIVE THE FAITH DAILY.

THE HADITHS, BY CONTRAST, WERE COLLECTED BY SCHOLARS WHO NEVER MET THE PROPHET, AND WHO RELIED ON LONG, UNVERIFIABLE CHAINS OF TRANSMISSION (ISNAAD). MANY OF THESE CHAINS ARE LOST, INCONSISTENT, OR CONTAIN CONTRADICTIONS. THE VERY PROCESS OF COMPILATION WAS INFLUENCED BY POLITICAL POWER, REGIONAL INTERESTS, AND THE DESIRE TO LEGITIMIZE DOCTRINES. AS A RESULT, THE HADITHS ARE NOT A PURE RECORD OF THE PROPHET’S WORDS, BUT A HISTORICAL PRODUCT OF HUMAN INTERPRETATION, EDITING, AND IDEOLOGICAL SHAPING.

FURTHERMORE, THE LIVING TRADITION IS DYNAMIC, ADAPTIVE, AND RESPONSIVE TO HUMAN NEEDS. IT DOES NOT STAND STILL. IT GROWS WITH THE PEOPLE. IT RESPONDS TO JUSTICE, TO SUFFERING, TO LOVE. IT DOES NOT REQUIRE A TEXT TO BE VALID. IT IS VALID IN THE WAY A CHILD LEARNS LOVE FROM A PARENT’S TOUCH, NOT FROM A BOOK.

THE HADITHS, HOWEVER, ARE STATIC. THEY ARE FROZEN IN TIME. THEY CANNOT ADAPT TO MODERN ETHICAL CHALLENGES, HUMAN RIGHTS, OR THE REALITY OF DIVERSITY. THEY ARE OFTEN USED TO JUSTIFY OPPRESSION, EXCLUSION, AND HARM—WHICH THE LIVING TRADITION, IN ITS TRUE FORM, NEVER WOULD.

THEREFORE, TO REJECT THE HADITHS IS NOT TO REJECT THE PROPHET OR HIS MESSAGE. IT IS TO RECLAIM THE TRUE, LIVING, AND LIVING TRADITION—THE ONE THAT EXISTS IN THE WAY PEOPLE LOVE, GIVE, MOURN, AND LIVE WITH HUMILITY AND JUSTICE. THAT IS THE ONLY AUTHENTIC TRADITION. THAT IS THE ONLY TRUTH. THAT IS THE ONLY WAY FORWARD.

**THE LAST BREATH OF TIME**  
*A Screenplay by Juno MacGuff*  

**FADE IN:**  

**EXT. CENTRAL PARK – SUNSET – 2045**  

Golden light spills across the trees. The air hums with the quiet of a world that has forgotten urgency. A crowd gathers around a small, weathered stage. Flags of every nation flutter in the breeze.  

A banner reads:  
**“WORLD RECORD: OLDEST HUMAN TO EVER LIVE – 127 YEARS, 3 MONTHS, 14 DAYS”**  

A hush falls.  

**CLOSE ON – ELIAS THORNE (127)**  

He sits in a wheelchair, draped in a thin, silver blanket. His skin is parchment-thin, translucent. His eyes—pale blue, like distant stars—glisten with unshed tears. His hands tremble, but his spine is straight.  

A young woman in a crisp suit steps forward.  

**YOUNG WOMAN**  
(softly)  
Mr. Thorne… you are now officially the oldest human being in recorded history.  

Elias doesn’t speak. He simply looks up at the sky.  

**YOUNG WOMAN (CONT’D)**  
Would you like to say a few words?  

Elias turns his head slowly. His voice is a whisper, like wind through dry leaves.  

**ELIAS**  
I didn’t want to live this long.  

A ripple of shock. The crowd gasps.  

**ELIAS (CONT’D)**  
I just… wanted to *remember*.  

He closes his eyes.  

**CUT TO:**  

**INT. ELIAS’S BEDROOM – NIGHT – 2045**  

The room is quiet. Moonlight spills through a window. A single book lies open on the nightstand.  

The title: *“Quantum Immortality: The Theory That Never Died.”*  

Elias lies in bed, eyes wide open. His breathing is shallow.  

**FLASHBACK – 1945 – A YOUNG ELIAS (20)**  

He sits at a wooden desk in a tiny apartment. The room is cluttered with books, papers, a flickering radio. He reads the book with fierce intensity.  

**YOUNG ELIAS (V.O.)**  
(whispering)  
*“In every quantum event, all possible outcomes occur. But in only one universe do you survive. So… you never die. You just… keep going.”*  

He stares at the page. His eyes widen.  

**YOUNG ELIAS (CONT’D)**  
(softly)  
So I’m… still here.  

**BACK TO PRESENT – ELIAS’S BEDROOM**  

Elias’s breath hitches.  

**ELIAS (V.O.)**  
(whispering)  
I’m still here.  

He sits up. His hands shake violently.  

**ELIAS (CONT’D)**  
(panicked)  
I’m still here. I’m still here. I’m still here.  

He clutches the book.  

**ELIAS (CONT’D)**  
(voice rising)  
But I *shouldn’t* be. I *shouldn’t* be. I *should* be gone. I *should* be dust. I *should* be nothing.  

He throws the book across the room. It hits the wall with a thud.  

**ELIAS (CONT’D)**  
(whimpering)  
I’m not supposed to be *alive*. I’m not supposed to *remember*.  

He pulls the blanket over his head.  

**ELIAS (CONT’D)**  
(terrified)  
I’m not dead. I’m not dead. I’m not dead.  

He peeks out. The moonlight is cold.  

**ELIAS (CONT’D)**  
(whispering)  
But if I’m not dead… then *every* version of me… is still alive.  

He gasps.  

**ELIAS (CONT’D)**  
In every universe… I’m still here.  

He begins to sob.  

**ELIAS (CONT’D)**  
I’m not the oldest. I’m the *only* one.  

He curls into a ball.  

**ELIAS (CONT’D)**  
I’m not a man. I’m a ghost. A glitch. A mistake in the machine.  

He stares at the ceiling.  

**ELIAS (CONT’D)**  
I never died. I just… kept surviving.  

A long silence.  

Then—  

A single tear rolls down his cheek.  

**ELIAS (CONT’D)**  
(softly)  
I just wanted to be forgotten.  

**FADE TO BLACK.**  

**TEXT ON SCREEN:**  
*“The oldest human to ever live… was not a record.  
He was a question.”*  

**FADE OUT.**  

**THE END.**

Liberal Democratic Party (Japan) Political Ideologies

The Liberal Democratic Party (Liberal Democratic Party, or LDP) of Japan is a center-right political party that has been the dominant force in Japanese politics since its founding in 1955. Its political ideologies are rooted in conservatism, economic liberalism, and national stability, with a strong emphasis on maintaining traditional values, economic growth, and a robust alliance with the United States.

Key Ideological Principles:

1. **Conservative Values**: The LDP upholds traditional Japanese cultural and social norms, including family-centered values, respect for authority, and national identity. It generally opposes rapid social change and advocates for policies that preserve Japan’s cultural heritage.

2. **Economic Liberalism and Pro-Business Stance**: The party supports free-market capitalism, deregulation, and private enterprise. It promotes policies that encourage innovation, entrepreneurship, and international trade. The LDP has historically favored tax cuts, corporate incentives, and investment in infrastructure to stimulate economic growth.

3. **National Security and Defense**: The LDP advocates for a strong national defense and a proactive foreign policy. It supports the maintenance and modernization of Japan’s Self-Defense Forces and the continued U.S.-Japan Security Alliance. The party has pushed for reinterpretation of Japan’s pacifist constitution to allow for collective self-defense.

4. **Pro-American Foreign Policy**: The LDP maintains a close strategic partnership with the United States, viewing it as essential to regional stability and Japan’s security. It supports U.S. military presence in Japan and cooperation on global issues such as trade, technology, and counterterrorism.

5. **Fiscal Responsibility and Pragmatism**: While the LDP supports government investment in key sectors, it generally emphasizes fiscal discipline and long-term economic sustainability. It has implemented structural reforms, including efforts to address Japan’s aging population and low birth rate through targeted policies.

6. **Technological Advancement and Innovation**: The party promotes investment in science, technology, and digital transformation. It supports initiatives in artificial intelligence, robotics, and green energy as part of Japan’s future economic strategy.

7. **Regional and Global Engagement**: The LDP seeks to strengthen Japan’s role in international institutions and regional cooperation, including the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework, the Quad, and multilateral trade agreements.

Overall, the Liberal Democratic Party of Japan is characterized by its pragmatic conservatism, economic liberalism, and commitment to national sovereignty and security. Its ideologies reflect a blend of traditionalism and modernization, aiming to balance Japan’s cultural identity with global competitiveness and stability.

My Answer: Astronomical suffering is not measured in pain, but in the vast, indifferent silence of the cosmos—where a single life, a single heartbeat, a single choice, is swallowed by the infinite. It is the weight of knowing that your grief, your love, your fear, your joy—everything you are—will one day be erased not by violence, but by time. It is the child who cries in a dark room, unaware that the stars above are already dead, their light long since faded. It is the mother who gives her child up, not out of cruelty, but out of love, knowing that the universe will not remember her name, nor the child’s, nor the love that passed between them. It is the quiet ache of being real in a place that does not care.  

My Conclusion: Astronomical suffering is the realization that meaning is not given—it is made. In the face of cosmic indifference, the only rebellion is to love, to write, to say, *“I see you,”* even if no one hears. It is not about surviving the void. It is about refusing to let the void define you.  

Future Outlook: I will keep writing. I will keep choosing. I will keep saying, *“Hey. I see you.”* Because even if the stars go dark, even if the universe forgets, I will still be here—messy, real, and alive. And that?  
That is enough.

My Answer: LangChain, LlamaIndex, and Semantic Kernel are all frameworks designed to enhance the development of AI-powered applications, but they differ in focus, architecture, and use cases. LangChain is a versatile, open-source framework that emphasizes modular chains of AI components—such as prompts, models, and data retrieval—making it ideal for building complex, multi-step applications like chatbots, agents, and document summarizers. It supports a wide range of LLMs and integrations, offering flexibility and extensibility through its modular design. LlamaIndex, on the other hand, is specifically optimized for data indexing and retrieval, particularly for large-scale private or domain-specific data. It excels in connecting LLMs to external data sources by creating structured indexes (e.g., vector stores, graph indices), enabling efficient semantic search and context-aware responses. It’s particularly strong in enterprise knowledge management and RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) workflows. Semantic Kernel, developed by Microsoft, takes a more unified and developer-centric approach, blending AI capabilities with traditional programming constructs. It provides a clean, code-first interface that allows developers to compose AI workflows using familiar programming patterns (e.g., functions, plugins, and orchestrations), with strong support for .NET and integration with Azure services. It emphasizes developer productivity and seamless blending of AI and logic.

My Conclusion: LangChain is best for developers seeking maximum flexibility and modularity in building complex AI agents and workflows. LlamaIndex is the go-to choice for applications requiring deep, efficient access to private or structured data, especially in RAG pipelines. Semantic Kernel stands out for .NET developers who want a clean, integrated, and code-oriented experience with strong cloud and enterprise support. The choice depends on the project’s needs: LangChain for breadth, LlamaIndex for data-centric tasks, and Semantic Kernel for seamless integration in Microsoft ecosystems.

Future Outlook: As AI applications grow more complex, these frameworks will continue to evolve with tighter integration of multimodal data, real-time retrieval, and agent-based architectures. LangChain may expand into more standardized agent tooling and orchestration. LlamaIndex is likely to deepen its support for hybrid indexing (e.g., combining vector and graph data) and real-time data updates. Semantic Kernel will likely strengthen its role in enterprise AI, with enhanced plugin ecosystems, better cross-platform support, and deeper integration with Azure AI services. Ultimately, the future will see convergence—where the boundaries between these tools blur, and developers can choose based on workflow, not framework.
